Sooo, we (depends of cultures too) haven't always been a monogamous species, it emerged roughly around 10,000 years ago during the dawn of agriculture.

The idea of resources and protection you gave seems like you've done a Flinstone's on the past (Modern culture projected onto history). Polyamory is the route of our relationships and is also evidenced in one of our most closest relatives, the bonobo chimp. If you look at sexual selection it mostly occurs at a sexual level (there are actually different kinds of sperms!). Look at the male to female size ratio of humans, compared to other monogamous relatives (gorilla) and you see ours is closer to a mixed relationship origin than purely monogamous. There's much more evidence which is in favour of polygamous origins making it harder to disprove.

Changes in culture, lifestyle and politics have created, reinforced and maintained a predominance of monogamous relationships.

Cheating is a construct created through monogamy - it's a social construct but it is real (maintained in the concept of monogamy if that makes sense). There are negative emotions, connotations and effects that occur from promiscuous behavior (cheating) within a monogamous structure.

My problem with this video is that it suggests monogamy is biologically determined and doesn't seem to mention any other factors like cultural, political or epistemological evidence, and goes straight for biological studies that don't seem to have Ultimate causation, remaining at a proximate level of research. the biology involved is a integral part of a larger theory of sexual relationships. We have choice in our actions, and not everything is biologically determined.

I'm not saying different sexual pairings are any better than the other - just needs to take a step back and look at monogamy (cheating) in the whole picture, not a snapshot like this.

I believe that it is more a social construct than any sort of embedded behavior.  Even going back to the caveman "partnering" up to provide while another protects doesn't guarantee that the male didn't have multiple partners within the group if he could provide for all (and 5 women protecting kids would be way safer than one woman protecting kids).  Since we no longer need that specific function for safety and with the knowledge of "love" being a chemical reaction not limited to one person demonstrates to me that deciding to settle with one person is a choice that is made, not some sort of evolutionary drive.  I would be interested to see how many humans settle down with the first person that they ever "fell in love" with and stayed with that person for life...I would wager that the number would be quite small.

It should be noted that humans are NOT naturally pair bonded. It is really common, and there is often natural wiring for it, BUT the dominance of that wiring varies by environmental factors. Critically though, the dominance of the pair bonding behavior is independent of the 'cheating' behavior since that occurs outside pair bonded structures too.

But the idea that we are fundamentally a pair bonded species is not accurate, or at minimal is a misleading simplification representing a bit of a retcon to explain modern behavior.
